It's not that, it's that the _implementation_ of IList (whatever that is in
LLBLGen) exposes Clear() but doesn't implement it (giving you
NotSupportedException). Though typically I'd see NotImplementedException.
Perhaps EntityView<T> implements IList?

On Mon, Oct 28, 2013 at 9:02 PM, stcts notifications@github.com wrote:

> var sourceLength = enumerableValue.Count;
> var destination = GetOrCreateDestinationObject(context, mapper,
> destElementType, sourceLength);
> var enumerable = GetEnumerableFor(destination);
> 
> ClearEnumerable(enumerable); ///ERROR HAPPENS HERE.
> 
> Object being passed in as enumerable.
> {SD.LLBLGen.Pro.ORMSupportClasses.EntityView2`1[[Storage.EntityClasses.AddressAllEntity,
> Storage, Version=1.0.5048.384, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]]}
> 
> which is an IList. IList.Clear() causes the exception inside of
> ClearEnumerable.
> 
> I'm trying to map a Model class to a LLBLGEN entity.
> 
> I guess the problem is that IList cannot be an enumerable type in
> AutoMapper?
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/404#issuecomment-27273222
> .
I think we need to summon @fransbouma here

What's the llblgen pro version we're talking about? The collection classes implement IListSource, which return an EntityView<T>, which is a view on the collection, based on a filter, and sorted with a sort expression, similar to dataview and its buddy datatable, so you can create multiple different views on the same collection based on different filters, sort clauses etc. 

The view's IList.Clear() isn't implemented as it doesn't make sense, as the view is not the container of the data but just a view on that data, it doesn't contain the objects, just indices in the collection it's a view on, the exception message therefore says "Clear the related collection instead", if you want to clear the collection. Example: you have 100 entities in a collection, you grab its view through the IListSource implementation and filter it so the view shows 15 entities. Now you do clear on the view: that's unclear (haha): do you want to remove the elements from the view or also from the collection. The view does support Remove though, we had the same exception for Remove as for Clear in the view, however as the view is mainly used for databinding, it's actually useful to have a view which allows you to remove elements from the underlying collection. But with Clear, that's IMHO a different thing, hence the exception.

The question now is: did you want to bind / map to the collection anyway and the IListSource implementation got in your way or did you intentionally bind / map to the view? If the latter, you should bind/map onto the collection instead and skip the IListSource, as it doesn't bind/map to the collection, but to a view. 

(disclaimer: I never used automapper, I have no idea if I made any sense :))
I think that semi-correct fix would be to move `ListSourceMapper` after `CollectionMapper` in `MapperRegistryOverride`

I am using llblgen 4.0.

I using MVC.  I have a Model objective coming back from the client.  Which has collections in it.  I'm using AutoMapper to map the Model object into a llblgen generated entity objective.  The entity objective has entity collections.

Ok. Did Hazzik's fix / workaround work for you? If you use it push data from client model -> entity model, you don't really need to call Clear, or am I overlooking something? Anyway, I've explained why this is happening. The best thing what could be done is that automapper is told to map to the collection, not to the IListSource returned object. I don't know whether that's possible, I'll leave that to the automapper specialists ;)

Ok, though I really wonder why it binds against the object returned by IListSource, if the data is in the object implementing IListSource: the object returned by IListSource will always be a subset of the real data, perhaps even different types, different order etc., than the actual object container one wants to connect with. 

But perhaps this is all configurable, don't know. I explained why the code throws the exception, in this case it's unfortunate, but it does make sense in general: the thing is though, is it necessary to bind to the element returned by IListSource or not...
So, given @FransBouma's response, can anything be done in AutoMapper to correct this?  Thank you.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
